G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20133.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1–3, because the cause of action arose in this county, where Defendant conducts business and the injury occurred.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of any unreasonable dangers of which the owner knows or should know.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case that abolished the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to all lawful visitors. The concurrence excerpted here critiques retaining a separate trespasser category, which implicitly confirms that, as to lawful entrants, the court has adopted a unified reasonable-care standard, including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers known or reasonably knowable. Thus, the case supports the stated proposition for lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion, not the concurrence excerpted): "We therefore hold that a landowner owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, the highest duty of care to maintain safe aisles and shelving.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case discusses premises liability duties generally and traces the historical invitee standard, but it is not about aisle or shelving safety and never states that a business invitee is owed ‘the highest duty of care.’ Instead, it reiterates the modern Massachusetts rule that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care under all the circumstances, treating former invitee status as the benchmark, not a special heightened duty. Thus, the opinion does not specifically support the proposition as phrased.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … During a period of ‘reconsideration and reform’… this court… applied the standard of reasonable care previously applied only to invitees to all but adult trespassers.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant breached its duty by negligently stacking and failing to secure merchandise, creating a foreseeable risk of falling objects, contrary to the standard articulated in Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973) (duty to protect against reasonably foreseeable hazards).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: Oliveri is a premises-liability slip-and-fall case involving a foreign substance on stairs, not negligent stacking or falling merchandise. While it does restate the general duty of a business owner to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe and to protect against dangers it knows or should know about, it does not involve or articulate any standard specific to stacking or securing merchandise or falling objects. Using Oliveri as authority for negligent stacking of goods mischaracterizes the case’s facts and holding, which focus instead on notice of a foreign substance and the time element for discovery and removal.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant’s failure to inspect or remedy dangerous shelf conditions constitutes negligence under Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) (landowners liable for hazards created by failure to act reasonably).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: Dos Santos concerns a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious danger that the landowner himself created and maintained (trampoline next to a shallow pool) when it is foreseeable that lawful entrants will encounter it. It does not address any duty to inspect or remedy ‘dangerous shelf conditions’ or any analogous failure-to-inspect theory; the liability discussion is about creating and maintaining an obviously hazardous configuration, not about inspection duties. Using this case as authority for negligence based on failure to inspect or remedy shelf conditions misstates its holding and context.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “‘While the open and obvious doctrine may relieve the defendant of its duty to warn, the doctrine does not mean that the defendant can maintain its property “in an unreasonably unsafe condition as long as the unsafe condition is open and obvious.”’ … Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool… for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool.… On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises–Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.proposition: The condition of Defendant’s merchandise display amounted to a hidden hazard that Defendant knew or should have known of through reasonable inspection, as recognized in Barry v. Beverly Enterprises–Massachusetts, Inc., 418 Mass. 590 (1994).
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Barry recognizes a hidden hazard that the defendant knew or should have known of through reasonable inspection. In fact, the court held the opposite: it found the evidence insufficient to infer that the defendant had actual or constructive notice of the icy condition, and reversed the earlier ruling that such an inference was permissible. Barry therefore undercuts, rather than supports, a claim that a hidden condition was one the defendant should have discovered through reasonable inspection on these facts.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises\u2013Massac.relevant_excerpt: “Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall. … There was no evidence that any of the defendant’s employees saw ice under the puddle on the morning of the accident or that the ice was even visible. … Thus, there was no evidence suggesting that the defendant was or should have been on notice that water and ice might accumulate in an unnatural and dangerous manner in its delivery area.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.proposition: The injuries and losses incurred by Plaintiff were the direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses proximate cause and specifically holds that the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence was not the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Rather than finding that the injuries were the direct and proximate result of the defendant’s negligence, the court concludes that intervening actions (by INS) were a superseding cause and that, as a matter of law, the causal chain was broken. Thus the case undermines, rather than supports, the proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were the direct and proximate result of defendant’s negligence.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.relevant_excerpt:
“We also conclude that the Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the plaintiffs’ negligence claims should have been granted because, as a matter of law, the decision of the Massachusetts parole board to release a violent prisoner…was not the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ injuries…
…Subsequent action by the INS releasing MacNeil in Massachusetts became a superseding cause of the harm he inflicted, relieving the Commonwealth of liability as a matter of law…there is no set of facts that the plaintiffs could prove to support a conclusion that the Commonwealth’s decision…was the proximate cause of Kent’s injuries.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated the general duty of care established by G.L. c. 231, § 85, requiring apportionment of fault only where the plaintiff’s negligence exceeds that of the defendant; here, Plaintiff was not negligent.

Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Ma.raw_text: Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Mass. 463 (1998)
Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s lack of merchandise-safety procedures breached standards of care consistent with Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Mass. 463 (1998), which emphasizes foreseeability and prevention of injury.
Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Ma.case_name: Quigley v. Bay State Graphics, Inc.
Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Ma.support_reasoning: The case concerns an insurance agent’s and insurer’s duties to third parties regarding procurement of insurance, not a merchant’s duty to implement merchandise-safety procedures. Its discussion of foreseeability is narrowly about whether third-party reliance on an agent’s promise to obtain insurance can create a duty, and the court ultimately finds no such duty. It does not establish or emphasize a general negligence standard about foreseeability and prevention of physical injury from unsafe merchandise or premises procedures, so using it for that proposition misstates its holding and context.
Peshkin v. Lynn Sand & Stone Co., 427 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In the absence of foreseeable reliance on the promised services being performed by someone, we have never held that ‘a promisor of services may be liable in tort not only to the promisee but also to potential beneficiaries of the promise.’ … Applying the Flattery test to the undisputed facts of this case, we conclude that the trustees have not established that they ‘rightfully and foreseeably’ relied on any promise by Cochrane & Porter to Bay State to obtain coverage naming them as loss payees….”

Jurkowski v. McPhee, 301 Mass. 242 (1938.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were reasonably foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s unsafe shelf arrangements, which constitute negligence under Jurkowski v. McPhee, 301 Mass. 242 (1938).
Jurkowski v. McPhee, 301 Mass. 242 (1938.support_reasoning: The case does not involve shelves or unsafe shelf arrangements; it concerns an automobile–pedestrian collision involving a child playing and running across a street. The court’s analysis focuses on a driver’s duty of care, foreseeability of children in the roadway, and contributory negligence of a child, not on premises liability or injuries resulting from unsafe shelving. Thus, Jurkowski v. McPhee cannot reasonably be cited for the proposition that injuries were foreseeable consequences of unsafe shelf arrangements constituting negligence.
Jurkowski v. McPhee, 301 Mass. 242 (1938.relevant_excerpt: "There was evidence to warrant finding the defendant negligent in not seeing the plaintiff as he ran across the road when the truck was far enough away so that the defendant could have avoided injury to the plaintiff by the application of his brakes or merely by continuing on his course, and negligent in unnecessarily permitting the truck to go upon the southerly half of the road and there come into collision with the plaintiff."

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct caused personal injuries and economic harm to Plaintiff, entitling Plaintiff to damages cognizable under Massachusetts common law of negligence.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The case squarely rejects imposing negligence liability on the defendant social host under these facts. The SJC holds that, where the host neither served nor provided alcohol and had no control over the liquor consumed by the intoxicated guest, there is no common-law duty to third persons injured by the guest’s driving. Thus, Ulwick does not support the proposition that defendant’s conduct caused injuries and economic harm cognizable under Massachusetts negligence law; instead, it holds the opposite as to this defendant’s liability.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff claims that these circumstances impose a common law duty in negligence on the defendant for the protection of travelers on the highways… We disagree… Here, the defendant did not serve or make any alcohol available to Salvatore. The McGuiggan decision, therefore, does not afford a basis for the imposition of a common law duty on this defendant… In the absence of such control in this case, we are not prepared to say that the common law should provide a remedy on the negligent encouragement theory advanced by the plaintiff.”

Poole v. Classon Enters., Inc., 74 Mass..raw_text: Poole v. Classon Enters., Inc., 74 Mass. App. Ct. 635 (2009)
Poole v. Classon Enters., Inc., 74 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct caused personal injuries and economic harm to Plaintiff, entitling Plaintiff to damages cognizable under Massachusetts common law of negligence.
Poole v. Classon Enters., Inc., 74 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses whether the defendant plumber’s conduct negligently caused a fire that damaged the plaintiff’s property and holds there is sufficient evidence for a factfinder to find negligence and causation under Massachusetts common law. The Appeals Court reverses summary judgment, concluding the admissible expert testimony and surrounding facts could support a negligence verdict and resulting damages for the plaintiff, thus recognizing cognizable negligence-based recovery for the harm alleged.
Poole v. Classon Enters., Inc., 74 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The defendant also urges that even if the expert’s opinion is admissible, the judgment should be affirmed, as there was insufficient evidence of negligence. We disagree. … We consider the foregoing evidence was sufficient for a fact finder to find that Paulo was negligent by not waiting until the pipes cooled before returning the cleaning rags and chemicals to their place under the sink. … The judgment for the defendant is reversed, and the matter is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award compensatory damages in an amount to be determined at trial, but not less than $25,000, plus interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
